entry.title: Metempsychosis - Godot Wild Jam
entry.content:
For the 17th Godot Wild Jam we made what I can only describe as a “turn based co-op escape room like adventure game”. You play together with a friend, either online, or on the same device. You’re stuck in a space ship, and you’re trying to find the way out together. The catch is that you are never playing together, and you don’t know what the other’s layout is like.

I wanted the soundtrack to be mysterious, quiet, and eerie. At first, I went with a mostly orchestral track. A few days into the jam, I realized it was not right. I started messing around with more layered synthesizers sound, with very minimal melodic lines.

There is a time limit for each player of 5 minutes. When there’s around 1 minute left, a heavy bass layer comes in, signifying the end. On top of that, whenever you enter a terminal, a low pass filter goes over the music, to signify focus. It is also intended to make room for the sound effects that play in the sound puzzle terminal. I wrote the dynamic layering and lowpass trigger myself in GDScript.

entry.title: Space Squids: Race in Space
entry.content:
This game was made during the Global Game Jam 2020. The theme was “repair”. We madea goofy racing game for 4 players. The goal is to dash your way around the course as fast as possible. Whenever you dash, you lose a tentacle. The catch is that you can pick up other squids’ and your own tentacles to get more boosts.

This game screams fun, goofiness, and silly. I spent the first evening sketching a melody, and eventually settled on one. I decided to make a synthy upbeat track, with some nice percussion.

entry.title: Forest - music for a painting
entry.content: As part of an assignment, I wrote music for a painting. I chose this beautiful painting by Ryuchi Yamashiro. The simplicity of it all immediately struck me. Through the use of a shakuhachi flute, granular synthesis, and FX chains, I wanted to try and evoke the feeling of a quiet forest, with a danger nearing. All the flute parts have been composed, performed, and recorded by me. It was important for me to use a real flute, as opposed to a virtual one, so I could get very strong experession into the parts.

entry.title: Dream Again
entry.content:
For an interactive narrative design seminar, we made a short game about a struggling artist who has nightmares about his abusive boss. This game was made in 10 days. As you can see by the thumbnail, it’s a very dark and moody game. Yet, there are short daylight sections. Contrast was vital. The forests and eerie colours immediately sparked drony synth sounds in me. I layered a lot of different sounds over each other, mostly just playing one note, fading in and out. I wanted to create a constant sense of dread in the music.

The main theme uses a piano. To create a connection between the main theme, which plays during the start of the game, and the dreams, I sampled a pianio and used it as a percussive sound in the dream sections. This added a sense of the world being morphed to the music.
